attributes.title: Examining the effect two-dimensional inclusion on group and identification when inclusion becomes an necessity
attributes.description:
Although the claim made by Optimal Distinctiveness Theory (ODT; Brewer, 1991) that inclusion (assimilation + differentiation needs) predicts group identification and well-being better than assimilation only, it has, to our knowledge, never been tested. Recent attempts to experimentally manipulate the two dimensions fell short in distinguishing them, such that participants generalized one dimension over the other. Assuming that inclusion might perhaps only have superior prediction over assimilation if inclusion becomes a necessity (i.e., if it is relevant that both dimensions are satisfied), we test longitudinal effects of a two-dimensional conceptualization of inclusion on group identification and well-being. Using existing data from the LISS panel, we additionally assess two forms of inclusion necessity (1. Identity threat and 2. Chronically high inclusion necessity)
For an overview of the ODT model, please see Figure 1 in the summary document attached to the study design section.

q1.value: Examining the effect two-dimensional inclusion on group and identification when inclusion becomes a necessity

q3.value:
Although the claim made by Optimal Distinctiveness Theory (ODT; Brewer, 1991) that inclusion (assimilation + differentiation needs) predicts group identification and well-being better than assimilation only, it has, to our knowledge, never been tested. Recent attempts to experimentally manipulate the two dimensions fell short in distinguishing them, such that participants generalized one dimension over the other. Assuming that inclusion might perhaps only have superior prediction over assimilation if inclusion becomes a necessity (i.e., if it is relevant that both dimensions are satisfied), we test longitudinal effects of a two-dimensional conceptualization of inclusion on group identification and well-being. Using existing data from the LISS panel, we additionally assess two forms of inclusion necessity (1. Identity threat and 2. Chronically high inclusion necessity)
For an overview of the ODT model, please see Figure 1 in the summary document attached to the study design section.

q4.value:
Following the Inclusion Identification Model (IIM; Adams et al., in prep.) 
oH1: Higher levels of assimilation and differentiation at t2 will be positively associated with higher levels of well-being at t4 (Hypotheses 1a + 1b; see Table 1 for all times of measurement). 
oH2: Higher levels of assimilation and differentiation at t2 will be positively associated with superordinate and subordinate group identity at t3 (Hypotheses 2a+ H2b). 
oH3: Higher levels of superordinate and subordinate group identity at t3 will be positively associated with well-being at t4 (Hypotheses 3a + 3b). 
oH4: Both superordinate and subordinate group identity at t3 will fully mediate the effect of assimilation and differentiation at t2 on well-being at t4 (Hypothesis 4). 

Following Optimal Distinctiveness Theory (ODT; Brewer, 1991)
oH5: The mediational model using full inclusion (combination of assimilation and differentiation) as a predictor will have a better model fit than the model using simple inclusion (assimilation only) as a predictor (Hypothesis 5).

Following inclusion necessity arguments (Master’s Thesis Luca Versteegen)
oH6: The mediation hypothesized in H4 will only occur when inclusion is a necessity, such that it is either moderated through the experience of threat at t3 (Hypothesis 6a) or through chronically high inclusion needs t1 (Hypothesis 6b).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will existing data from the Immigrant Panel in the LISS panel (Scherpenzeel & Das, 2010). The Immigrant Panel is a representative sample obtained from true probability sampling in the Netherlands. About 1,700 of the 2,400 participants are of non-Dutch origin. At the time of data collection, participants were 16 years of age or older (for more information on the panel, see https://www.lissdata.nl/about-panel).
o	As can be seen in Table 1, we will use demographic variables and indicators of chronically high inclusion needs assessed in 2010 (t0). From 2011 data (t1), we will derive baseline well-being measures, as well as the model predictors assimilation and differentiation. The model mediators, superordinate and subordinate identity, as well as a second form of inclusion necessity, identity threat, will be derived from 2013 data (t3). Finally, the model outcome, well-being, will be taken from data collected in 2014 (t4).

q9.value: Given this is existing longitudinal data, we will not use any randomization.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value:
We will use existing data from the Immigrant Panel in the LISS panel (Scherpenzeel & Das, 2010). The Immigrant Panel is a representative sample obtained from true probability sampling in the Netherlands. About 1,700 of the 2,400 participants are of non-Dutch origin. At the time of data collection, participants were 16 years of age or older (for more information on the panel, see https://www.lissdata.nl/about-panel). Maximal one member per household was assessed, 
and reminders were sent out twice. All participants had given informed consent. Whereas some core questions were assessed longitudinally (starting October 2007 – ongoing), particular concepts were assessed in single waves only. Thus, the possibility to draw causal conclusions depends on the construct under discussion. In this project, we used data from five questionnaires.
We have browsed the panel to identify the required variables and to examine coherence of response patterns across data sets to assure sufficient power. We have created a "basket" of all required variables that has not yet been downloaded. 








Scherpenzeel, A.C., and Das, M. (2010). “True” Longitudinal and Probability-Based Internet Panels: Evidence From the Netherlands. In Das, M., P. Ester, and L. Kaczmirek (Eds.), Social and Behavioral Research and the Internet: Advances in Applied Methods and Research Strategies. (pp. 77-104). Boca Raton: Taylor & Francis.

question.value:
No data for this study will be collected. Information about the sample, response rates, inclusion and exclusion criteria can be found in the material posted above. 

We do not plan to exclude any participants from the existing data sets as we are currently not aware of any issues with the completed participations.

q13.value: The required sample size for this study is N = 200. We expect that the 2,400 participants in the Immigrant Panel should allow to derive at least N = 200 cases that cover all relationships as suggested in the model.

q14.value: We conducted a power analyses using the R findRMSEAsamplesize function and guidance by MacCallum, Browne, & Sugaware (1996) to have a sufficient power of 1-ß = .8, alpha = .05, Null-RMSEA = .05, Alternative RMSEA = .08. Additionally, power analyses using G*Power 3 (Faul, Erdfelder, & Buchner, & Lang, 2009) suggested that this sample size will suffice for regression analyses.

q15.value: As there will be no data collection, no stopping rule applies. For analysis, we intend to use all data we have to increase power and validity of the sample. Therefore, no participants will be excluded even if we exceed the required sample size.

question.value: No variables will be manipulated in this study.

Assimilation and differentiation (2010, t0): 10 items from the multiculturalism questionnaire (https://www.dataarchive.lissdata.nl/study_units/view/170; Van De Vijver, 2010). We used 4 items for assimilation (E.g., “It is best for the Netherlands if all people forget their different cultural backgrounds as soon as possible.”) and 4 items for differentiation (E.g., “Ethnic minorities should be helped to preserve their cultural heritage in the Netherlands”). The remaining 2 items were excluded because they combined assimilation and differentiation (i.e., what we would term full inclusion). All items were rated from 1 (Completely disagree) to 5 (Completely agree).

Superordinate Dutch identity (2013, t3): 5 items from the Migrants National Identification and the National Dimension of Cultural Consumption Data Set (https://www.dataarchive.lissdata.nl/study_units/view/453), such as “I feel connected to other Dutch people.” (all 1 (Disagree entirely) – 5 (Agree entirely)).

Subordinate ethnic identity (2013, t3): 5 items from the Migrants National Identification and the National Dimension of Cultural Consumption Data Set (https://www.dataarchive.lissdata.nl/study_units/view/453), such as “I feel connected to [insert ethnic group].” (all 1 (Disagree entirely) – 5 (Agree entirely)).

Life satisfaction (2011, t2 & 2014, t4): Assessed as baseline and outcome. Five-item Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS; Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985) from the Personality Data Set (https://www.dataarchive.lissdata.nl/physical_data_products/view/170) . E.g.; "If I could live my life over, I would change almost nothing." (all 1 (Strongly disagree) – 7 (Strongly agree)). 

Identity threat (Inclusion necessity 1; 2013; t3): 2 Items from the Migrants National Identification and the National Dimension of Cultural Consumption Data Set (https://www.dataarchive.lissdata.nl/question_constructs/view/15857) : “It would be a better world if people from other countries were more like [fillF].” And “The culture of [insert ethnic group] in the Netherlands is under threat.” (Both 1 (Disagree entirely) – 5 (Agree entirely)). 

Chronically high inclusion need (Inclusion necessity 2; 2010, t1): 3 items from the Health Data Set (https://www.dataarchive.lissdata.nl/control_construct_schemes/view/139), asking for 1. General health (1 (Poor) – 5 (Excellent), 2. Chronic disease (Yes/No), and 3. The extent to which the individual cannot exert daily activities because of physiological or psychological health issues  (1 (Not at all) – 5 (Very much)). 

Background and control variables: Gender, age, relationship status, highest education, net income, occupation status, origin group (Dutch, first or second generation foreign in first or second generation), country of origin (Netherlands, Morocoo, Netherlands Antilles, Suriname, Indonesia, other Western origin, other non-Western origin). All background variables are from the Background Data Set, https://www.dataarchive.lissdata.nl/study_units/view/323). 
o	religiosity (yes/no), religion (choice of 14 religions) (both from the Religion and Ethnicity Data Set, 2011, t2, https://www.dataarchive.lissdata.nl/study_units/view/207) 
o	Affect (2011, t2 & 2014, t4): 20-item version of the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS; Watson, Clark & Tellegen, 1988). E.g., "Indicate to what extent you feel this in general: upset." (all 1 (Not at all) - 7 (Extremely)).

We will compute a mean score for the following measures: 
– Assimilation (4 variables) 
– Differentiation (4 variables)
– Superordinate Dutch identity (5 variables) 
– Subordinate ethnic identity (5 variables) 
– Life satisfaction well-being t2 and t4 (5 variables each) 
– Identity threat (2 variables) 
– Positive Affect (10 variables) 
– Negative Affect (10 variables)

We will first conduct preliminary analyses to examine missingness of data, outliers, and influential data points. Next, we will examine psychometrics and factor structure of all scales, as well as descriptive analyses (Means) and correlation analyses. 

To test the hypotheses, we will conduct hierarchical regression for the following outcomes. 

oHypothesis 1: We will regress life satisfaction on three models (Model 1: background variables, Model 2: background variables + positive and negative affect; Model 3: background variables + positive and negative affect + assimilation + differentiation).

oHypothesis 2: We will regress the superordinate Dutch identity and the subordinate ethnic identity on three models separately (Model 1: background variables, Model 2: background variables + positive and negative affect; Model 3: background variables + positive and negative affect + assimilation + differentiation)

oHypothesis 3: We will regress life satisfaction on three models (Model 1: background variables, Model 2: background variables + positive and negative affect; Model 3: Demographics + positive and negative affect + superordinate and subordinate identity)

oHypothesis 4: We will regress life satisfaction on four models (Model 1: background variables, Model 2: background variables + positive and negative affect; Model 3: background variables + positive and negative affect + superordinate and subordinate identity; Model 4: background variables + positive and negative affect + superordinate and subordinate identity + assimilation and differentiation)

oHypothesis 5: We will compare model fit in Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) using the R-package lavaan to compare two models (Model 1: using full inclusion conditions (assimilation + differentiation); Model 2: using simple inclusion (assimilation only) as predictors)).

oHypothesis 6: We will compare model fit in Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) using the R-package lavaan to compare multiple models.
First, we will compare full inclusion (assimilation + differentiation, Model 1) with simple inclusion (Assimilation only, Model 2) when moderated by identity threat. 
Second, we will compare full inclusion (assimilation + differentiation, Model 3) with simple inclusion (Assimilation only, Model 4) when moderated by chronically high inclusion needs.

q20.value:
Reverse-coded items in the scales will be recoded. As indicated above, a mean score will be computed for the two identity, the two well-being, and the two affect scales. 
Categorical background variables (relationship status, education level, religion, origin group, country of origin) will be dummy coded.
No other data transformations are intended by now.

q21.value:
We will use p < .05 as criterion of significance, as well as the adequate effect size in hierarchical regression and SEM. 
In case of multiple comparisons, we will use the post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test as a correction tool.

q22.value: We will exclude participants only if we have strong indication that the participation was abnormal (i.e., no attention).

q23.value: The cause of potential missingness will be examined through missingness simulations and, in case of missingness not at random (MNAR, Scheffer, 2002), I will conduct maximum likelihood imputation.

q24.value:
We will follow the modification indices provide in SEM to explore if other theoretical considerations provide better fit. This will be done when backed up by theory and substantial reasoning.

We will further explore if any demographics (especially particular countries) affect single variables or the general statistical results.
As we are running analyses in different groups of origin, it might be fruitful to examine differences between majority and minority groups if these analyses are sufficiently powered.
In case the assimilation and differentiation indices are unrelated to the other variables, we will consider conducting Principle Component Analysis (PCA) to find potential other variables that are related to the experience of inclusion. 

Finally, as listed in the measurement variables section, we will only use the 8 assimilation and differentiation items from the 10-item Acculturation Scale by Van De Vijver (2010). Therefore, we will exploratively examine if the two inclusion items that we have excluded does predict group identification even better than the assimilation items (simple inclusion), or even better than the assimilation items in combination with the differentiation items (full inclusion)

q25.value: This pre-registration is part of the Master’s Thesis by Luca Versteegen, Tilburg University. Please also have a look at a related project in this Thesis: Comparing the influence of inclusion vs. assimilation on group identification and well-being when inclusion becomes a necessity.

attributes.title: Can We Emulate Pre-referential Knowledge in Adults? An EEG Study

q1.value: Can We Emulate Pre-referential Knowledge in Adults? An EEG Study

q2.value: Lewis Ball, Colin Bannard, Perrine Brusini

q3.value:
Previous research exploring the roles of Event-Related Potentials (ERPs) in lexical acquisition have suggested that different levels of word knowledge are dissociable and reflected by unique ERPs (Friedrich, 2017). Associative word knowledge - the pairing of phonological and visual representations- appears to be reflected by the N200 - 500 component (Friedrich & Friederici, 2005 ; 2010). Referential knowledge on the other hand - the pairing of a word to semantic representations- is reflected via well the well documented N400 component (Kutas & Federmeier, 2011). Such components have previously been observed in both infants and adults (Friedrich & Friederici, 2004). 

It has been proposed that at some point during development infants shift exclusively to a referential mode of lexical acquisition (Nazzi & Bertoncini, 2003). Does this mean therefore that associative knowledge is completely abandoned later in life, or does it still exist in adult speakers, perhaps as an initial foundation for learning new words? Indeed, research by Kutas et al (2018) failed to observe an N400 in participants 30 minutes after learning novel word - object pairings. Despite this, participants still performed well on behavioral measures testing for knowledge of these novel words.

The current study will attempt to answer the question proposed above by teaching novel words to adult speakers. Following learning we will measure ERPs in response to these novel words, and compare to ERPs produced whilst processing familiar words. In addition, we will conduct a short explicit test of knowledge for our novel stimuli at the end of the session to compare behavioural results with electrophysiological responses. Previous research has revealed good explicit test knowledge shortly after learning in the absence of an N400 effect (Kaczer et al, 2018).

q4.value: In response to processing novel words, we expect participants to display an N200 - 500 component in the absence of an N400 component. In contrast, we expect participants to display both an N200 - 500 and N400 component when processing familiar words. Despite an absent N400 component for our novel stimuli, we nonetheless expect participant to perform above chance levels during the explicit test of knowledge.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This experiment will be divided into two phases: A training phase and testing phase. In the training phase participants will have the opportunity to learn novel word - object pairings. The same 16 word - object pairings will be used across participants. Please see the attached file 'Training phase design' for a visual description of the training phase.

The testing phase will also employ a within-subjects design as participants will encounter the same 4 experimental conditions. In order to elicit our two ERPs of interest, two experimental conditions are necessary. Half of our trials will be 'congruous' trials. In such trials participants will be presented with an onscreen image (i.e, the image of a car), and after a short duration will hear the appropriate word for that image (i.e. the word 'car'). The other half of trials will be 'incongruous' trials. Here, participants will see an onscreen image (the image of a car) but will hear an inappropriate label (i.e. the word 'dog'). Such design is necessary as larger N200 - 500 components are elicited via congruous pairings, whereas N400 components appear more extreme to incongruous pairings (Friedrich, 2017).

Half of each trial type (congruous and incongruous) will contain novel stimuli, and the other half familiar stimuli, In total this creates 4 experimental conditions. See the attached file 'Testing phase design' for a visual description of this phase of the experiment. The order of presentations will be randomised for each participant. 

Following the testing phase participants will take part in a short test of explicit knowledge. For a single trial in this session will involve a novel image appearing in the centre of the screen. Two novel words (written) will also be present on screen, when to the left of the image and one to the right. Participants are simply asked to indicate which of the novel words they believe refers to the onscreen image. 

See the attached spreadsheet 'StimuliFile.xls' for the full list of stimuli and stimuli pairings

question.value: Participants will be adults (18 years and above) and recruited via advertisement on a participant recruitment website. Participants will receive course credit for completing the study.  Individuals suffering from neurological conditions, hearing or visual impairments will be ineligible to take part in this study.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 25 participants. This does not include excluded participants. Data collection will cease at the end of university term even if the 25 target sample isn't reached.

question.value: We will manipulate the level of congruity (congruous or incongruous pairing) and familiarity (novel or familiar stimuli) participants are exposed to on a trial-by-trial basis.
For each trial we will measure scalp voltage changes via 128 channel Geodesic HydroCel sensor net.
For a single participant, a mean will be generated for each condition (at each time point and electrode) by collapsing across trials for each of the four experimental conditions.

To test our hypothesis we will conduct two non-parametric, cluster based permutation analyses (Moris & Oostenveld, 2007)- one analyses for familiar words and one for novel words. This analyses works by removing condition labels from the raw data and randomly shuffling the data across multiple iterations. At each iteration a t-statistic is generated at each electrode and time point. Contiguous electrodes with similar t-statistics are considered a cluster, and at each iteration data from the biggest cluster is stored. After each iteration is completed the observed t-statistic (t-statistic from the largest cluster of electrode when comparing across conditions) is compared to the distribution of t-statistics stored and generated from the permutation. If the observed statistic falls within the 5 percentile of the distribution this will be considered a statistically significant cluster. This sort of analyses will help combat against the multiple comparisons problem often encountered in studies using ANOVAs.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for identifying significant clusters of electrodes. A cluster of electrodes which has a p value below this threshold will be considered statistically significant.

q22.value: Raw data from each participant will be subject to artifact detection. Participants who do not provide enough clean trials for each condition (36 clean trials per condition) will not be included in the final analyses.

q23.value: Participants who do not provide data for 90% of trials will be excluded from the analyses.

registration_responses.q1: Can We Emulate Pre-referential Knowledge in Adults? An EEG Study
registration_responses.q2: Lewis Ball, Colin Bannard, Perrine Brusini
registration_responses.q3:
Previous research exploring the roles of Event-Related Potentials (ERPs) in lexical acquisition have suggested that different levels of word knowledge are dissociable and reflected by unique ERPs (Friedrich, 2017). Associative word knowledge - the pairing of phonological and visual representations- appears to be reflected by the N200 - 500 component (Friedrich & Friederici, 2005 ; 2010). Referential knowledge on the other hand - the pairing of a word to semantic representations- is reflected via well the well documented N400 component (Kutas & Federmeier, 2011). Such components have previously been observed in both infants and adults (Friedrich & Friederici, 2004). 

It has been proposed that at some point during development infants shift exclusively to a referential mode of lexical acquisition (Nazzi & Bertoncini, 2003). Does this mean therefore that associative knowledge is completely abandoned later in life, or does it still exist in adult speakers, perhaps as an initial foundation for learning new words? Indeed, research by Kutas et al (2018) failed to observe an N400 in participants 30 minutes after learning novel word - object pairings. Despite this, participants still performed well on behavioral measures testing for knowledge of these novel words.

The current study will attempt to answer the question proposed above by teaching novel words to adult speakers. Following learning we will measure ERPs in response to these novel words, and compare to ERPs produced whilst processing familiar words. In addition, we will conduct a short explicit test of knowledge for our novel stimuli at the end of the session to compare behavioural results with electrophysiological responses. Previous research has revealed good explicit test knowledge shortly after learning in the absence of an N400 effect (Kaczer et al, 2018).
registration_responses.q4: In response to processing novel words, we expect participants to display an N200 - 500 component in the absence of an N400 component. In contrast, we expect participants to display both an N200 - 500 and N400 component when processing familiar words. Despite an absent N400 component for our novel stimuli, we nonetheless expect participant to perform above chance levels during the explicit test of knowledge.

attributes.title: Do liars really remember what they said?

q1.value: Do liars really remember what they said?

q3.value: The present study aims to investigate whether liars (i.e. fabrication group vs distortion group) are able to correctly recognize the details that they have previously fabricated from what they actually have seen and whether fabricators believe in their answers.

q4.value: It is expected that: (i) Participants that fabricate completely new details about an event will have a lower memory performance in recalling original details of the event than who partially distorted details and participants that told the truth, (ii) Participants that fabricate completely new details about an event will have a higher memory performance in the recognition of details said in the first session than who partially distorted details and participants that told the truth (iii) belief ratings will be higher for those fabricate completely new details than who partially distorted details and participants that told the truth.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: Three to six participants will be recruited for participation. The number of sessions for each participant will be in accordance with those needed to adhere to What Works Clearinghouse standards for rigor and based on the design logic of a multiple-probe single-case design.

analyses.value: Visual analysis using guidelines outlined by What Works Clearinghouse will be the primary means of evaluating our intervention and answering our research question. We may fit our data to multi-level models based on recommendations by Moeyaert and Manalov in order to estimate the effects of our intervention, but the values derived from these estimates (e.g., p-values, confidence interval) will not be used to determine a functional relation between our independent variable and the dependent variable.

outliers.value: Not applicable given that we are using a single-case research design.

dependent.value:
Baseline and Intervention Sessions – Trial-based Child Behavior

All of these behaviors will be recorded within the context of a trial (i.e., a child’s initiation to the environmental arrangement strategy begins the trial and 5 s following the final adult prompt [if used] ends the trial). Trial-by-trial event recording using a data sheet will be used.

Trial-based (TB) during the session: 

•	Initiation - Child response to instructor planned or unplanned environmental arrangement strategy to which the instructor begins a trial. Response can take the form of a secondary indicator of meaning or any other defined child communicative behavior. Planned environmental arrangement strategy occurs when instructor indicates that they are about to conduct a trial. Unplanned environmental arrangement strategy may occur when child demonstrates interest in an item other than what is currently available (e.g., child points to item on shelf) or an opportunity presents itself during a turn-taking activity (e.g., stacking blocks, doing puzzle, rolling ball). There may be other environmental arrangement strategies that occur but are not listed here.

•	Occurrence of Non-Target Communication - Did the following behaviors happen at least once during the trial? Code “yes” if the behavior occurred at least once (do not code how many times the behavior occurred). Code for each behavior listed:
o	TB communicative gesture is defined as the child’s non-vocal attempts to communicate, specifically (a) reaching for an item being held by adult, (b) pointing to an item, or (c) showing (holding an item in an adult’s field of vision; communicates interest) or giving an item to adult (placing an item in adult’s hand or in front of or near adult). 
o	TB non-word vocalization is defined as the child verbally attempting to communicate using exclamations (e.g., Whoa!, Oh!) or non-functional sounds (e.g., guttural sound). 
o	TB word vocalization is defined as verbal attempts to communicate using a word-based vocalization or approximation of a word (i.e., vocalization of a word may include a combination of the beginning and medial sound, but not the ending sound), other than the target expanded vocalization. 

•	Occurrence of Target Vocal Communication - Code presence or absence of an independent or a prompted response – both cannot occur in the trial (e.g., if “yes” for prompted expanded vocalization, code “no” for expanded vocalization):
o	TB prompted expanded vocalization, which is defined as the child emitting a target vocal response within 5 s of an adult’s verbal model of an expanded target vocalization. It should be noted than an approximation of the targeted vocalization, whether independent or prompted, is acceptable when recording a child’s response.
o	TB expanded vocalization is defined as the child emitting a target vocal response within 5 s of an adult’s initial cue to communicate (i.e., environmental arrangement strategy). This variable is used as our primary dependent variable on which experimental decisions will be based. 

•	TB unobservable should be recorded when the view of the data collector is obstructed, preventing the data collector to see or hear the interactions. Communicate with implementer when this occurs.

conditions.value: This study has been designed to meet What Works Clearinghouse (WWC) guidelines without reservations utilizing a multiple probe across participants research design. We will adhere to the following guidelines for single-case designs (SCD) provided by WWC (Kratochwill et al., 2010): (a) probe data will be collected for all tiers for the first three sessions with five data points collected in Tier 1; (b) probe data will be collected a minimum of five sessions prior to introducing the treatment package across all remaining tiers; (c) probe data will be collected on untreated tiers at least every seven sessions; (d) at least one data point will be collected in all tiers immediately before the intervention is introduced to any one tier.

hypothesis.value: Is a naturalistic language intervention implemented within public elementary school classrooms functionally related to increases in expressive vocal communication (i.e., expanded forms of vocalizations) in children with cognitive and social-communication delay? We hypothesize that variables other than our primary dependent variable (i.e,. expanded forms of vocalization) will change when our intervention is introduced for each participant within a single-case multiple probe design.

attributes.title: Video-Recording Eyewitness Identification Lineups: Testing for Unanticipated Costs and Undiscovered Benefits

q1.value: Do witnesses display non-verbal cues to accuracy?

q2.value: Kureva Matuku, Steve D. Charman, Amy Douglass

q3.value:
The first question this study addresses is whether witnesses exhibit non-verbal cues to accuracy while making their identification decision. This question is critical because researchers have uncovered only a small number of cues to witness accuracy (called ‘postdictors’), the utility of which can be questionable. For example, even though identification speed is a reliable cue to accuracy (i.e., witnesses who make quick decisions tend to be more accurate than witnesses who take long decisions; Brewer et al., 2006), without a video record, there is no accurate measure of how long a witness took to make a decision (Wells & Bradfield, 1998). Another known postdictor relates to witnesses’ descriptions of how their decision was made; witnesses who describe a deliberative process tend to be less accurate than those who describe an automatic process (e.g., the culprit’s photo ‘popped out,’ Dunning & Stern, 1994). However, these self-reports are themselves distorted by post-identification variables, such as feedback about accuracy, underming their reliability (Wells & Bradfield, 1998). A third postdictor of accuracy, witness confidence, can strongly postdict witness accuracy under ‘pristine’ conditions, but can fail to postdict accuracy strongly if not collected immediately after the identification, or in the presence of memory-distorting variables (Wixted & Wells, 2017). One of the main problems with these postdictors, therefore, is that they rely on self-reports, which can be subject to distortion. The discovery of postdictors that are not subject to self-report would therefore be highly desirable (e.g., Charman & Cahill, 2012). Consequently, we examine whether witnesses’ non-verbal behaviors during a lineup procedure—which can only be uncovered by video-recording their identifications—can postdict accuracy. Such non-verbal postdictors are particularly desirable given their lower susceptibility to distortion. Therefore, this study examines whether there are behavioral cues that can differentiate accurate from inaccurate witnesses. 
The second question this study addresses is whether video-recording affects the identification decisions that witnesses make. If video-recording does not affect witnesses’ decisions, this experiment will be a critical supplement to persuasive attempts to encourage police departments to adopt video-recording. However, if video-recording does affect choosing, this would be essential information for psychological researchers to know before continuing to advocate for this recommendation. Why might video-recording affect witness choosing? One possibility is that video-recording makes the potential for contradiction or embarrassment salient. If so, witnesses’ willingness to choose a photo (and potentially be wrong) might diminish, or witnesses may express lower confidence in their identifications. Research showing that witnesses produce lower confidence reports in public (cf. private) provides some support for this possibility (Shaw, Appio, Zerr, & Pontoski, 2007; Shaw, Zerr, & Woythaler, 2001). Alternatively, video-recording might make witnesses more likely to choose a photo because they want to show others that they are a ‘good’ witness. Therefore, as described below, we manipulate whether witnesses are aware of being video-recorded during their lineup procedure, and, among those who are aware, whether they are told that video-recording is standard protocol (thereby minimizing the salience of subsequent evaluation) or whether they are told it will be evaluated by peers (thereby maximizing the salience of potential negative evaluations). Should witness choosing and/or confidence be affected by the explanation for the video-recording, our data will advance our understanding of theoretical models of eyewitness decision-making by, for instance, expanding the constellation of variables known to shift witnesses’ willingness to choose (i.e., their decision criterion, e.g., Dobolyi & Dodson, 2013; Palmer & Brewer, 2012).

q4.value: We expect inaccurate witnesses to show more non-verbal signs of uncertainty, specifically touching the face while examining the photospread, making noises suggestive of uncertainty (e.g., sighs, groans), re-adjusting the lineup, and displaying facial signs of uncertainty (e.g., grimacing), and non-verbal wavering (e.g., going back and forth between two photos). Given multiple possible hypotheses regarding the effect of videotaping on witness choosing and/or confidence, we treat these questions as exploratory, and thus do not make predictions.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: Personnel will be blind only to the photospread condition (i.e., whether the culprit is in the lineup or not).

question.value: This experiment will be a 3 (Video: Standard Protocol vs. Evaluation vs. Surreptitious) x 2 (Photospread: Culprit-absent vs. Culprit-present) fully randomized between-participants factorial. In order to increase the generalizability of these findings (e.g., Wells & Windschitl, 1999), we will use three different non-violent mock crimes, each with a different perpetrator. Participants will be randomly assigned to view one of the three crime videos. Separate photospreads will be created for each mock crime. Culprit-present photospreads will consist of a picture of the perpetrator and five fillers; culprit-absent photospreads will consist of six fillers (no a priori innocent suspect).

q9.value: This study will use block randomization, where each participant is randomly assigned to one of 18 equally sized, predetermined blocks. The random number list used to create the 18 blocks will be created using https://www.random.org/

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Undergraduate participants will be recruited through advertisements on SONA Systems. Participants will be given a $5 gift card and a course credit for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old to take part in the study.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 900 participants.

q14.value: Because we have two main research questions (i.e., whether non-verbal cues postdict witness accuracy, and whether videotaping affects witness choosing/confidence), our required sample size is determined by the analysis that requires more participants. As we explain in more detail below (in the analysis section), testing the effects of videotaping on witness choosing behavior requires an ROC analysis to differentiate between changes in decision criterion and changes in discriminability (e.g., see Wixted & Mickes, 2012); because ROC analyses require particularly large numbers of participants to run, our sample size requirement is based off of this analysis. ROC analyses within eyewitness studies tend to use sample sizes of approximately 220-300 participants per ROC curve (e.g., Gronlund et al., 2012; Mickes, Flowe, & Wixted, 2012). Because we will construct 3 such curves (one for each video condition), we will therefore collect a total of 900 participants (300/condition).

q15.value: Sign up slots will be posted for each week on the preceding Wednesday, with 80 spots posted per week. We will post 80 new slots each week if on that Wednesday, we are below 900 participants. Once we have reached at least 900 participants we will stop data collection.

question.value: Our first manipulated variable in this experiment is the culprit’s presence in the lineup, therefore there were two levels: Culprit present; Culprit absent. Our second manipulated variable is the instructions regarding videotaping. There are three levels: Witnesses will be (a) told that video-recording is standard protocol for eyewitness experiments (Standard), (b) told that the video record of their identification will be evaluated by others (Evaluation), or (c) witnesses will be recorded, but only surreptitiously (Control).

Videos will be coded for non-verbal behaviors related to uncertainty such as: touching the face while examining the photospread, making noises suggestive of uncertainty (e.g., sighs, groans), re-adjusting the lineup, and displaying facial signs of uncertainty (e.g., grimacing), and non-verbal wavering (e.g., going back and forth between two photos). We will collect participants' identification decisions (Suspect 1-6; or Not There). These will be used to create variables on accuracy and choosing. We will also collect the participants' confidence statement (0-100%). These data will allow us to construct ROC curves. Additionally, testimony-relevant judgments will be measured using the following statements (scale from 1 to 7): To what extent do you feel you had a good basis (enough information) to make an identification? How easy or difficult was the lineup task for you? After you were first presented with the photos, how long do you estimate it took you to make an identification? How clear an image of the perpetrator did you have? How good of a view of the perpetrator did you have? How long would you estimate that the perpetrator’s face was in sight? How well are you able to make out specific features of the perpetrator? How far away was your view of the perpetrator? How much attention did you pay to the perpetrator? How strong is your memory of the perpetrator? How willing are you to testify that you made the correct identification? We will also ask participants during debriefing whether they believed knowledge being recorded did affect/would have affected their identification decisions (Yes/No). If yes, participants will be asked to indicate the lineup decision they would have otherwise made (suspect 1-6, or Not There).

To address whether non-verbal behavioral cues postdict accuracy, we will first conduct Chi-Square analyses that compare the proportion of accurate vs. inaccurate witnesses that exhibit each individual cue. This will provide data on the postdictive abilities of each individual cue (i.e., the extent to which each cue differentiates between accurate and inaccurate witnesses). To address whether video-recording affects witness choosing, we will conduct receiver-operator characteristic (ROC) analysis (e.g., Mickes, Flowe, & Wixted, 2012). Separate ROC curves will be calculated for each of the three video conditions. The partial area under the curves (pAUC) will then be compared; differences in pAUC are interpreted as differences in witnesses’ ability to empirically discriminate between innocent and guilty suspects.

q24.value: We will conduct exploratory analyses on the the effect of video-recording instructions on nonverbal sign of uncertainty, choosing, and confidence.

registration_responses.q1: Do witnesses display non-verbal cues to accuracy?
registration_responses.q2: Kureva Matuku, Steve D. Charman, Amy Douglass
registration_responses.q3:
The first question this study addresses is whether witnesses exhibit non-verbal cues to accuracy while making their identification decision. This question is critical because researchers have uncovered only a small number of cues to witness accuracy (called ‘postdictors’), the utility of which can be questionable. For example, even though identification speed is a reliable cue to accuracy (i.e., witnesses who make quick decisions tend to be more accurate than witnesses who take long decisions; Brewer et al., 2006), without a video record, there is no accurate measure of how long a witness took to make a decision (Wells & Bradfield, 1998). Another known postdictor relates to witnesses’ descriptions of how their decision was made; witnesses who describe a deliberative process tend to be less accurate than those who describe an automatic process (e.g., the culprit’s photo ‘popped out,’ Dunning & Stern, 1994). However, these self-reports are themselves distorted by post-identification variables, such as feedback about accuracy, underming their reliability (Wells & Bradfield, 1998). A third postdictor of accuracy, witness confidence, can strongly postdict witness accuracy under ‘pristine’ conditions, but can fail to postdict accuracy strongly if not collected immediately after the identification, or in the presence of memory-distorting variables (Wixted & Wells, 2017). One of the main problems with these postdictors, therefore, is that they rely on self-reports, which can be subject to distortion. The discovery of postdictors that are not subject to self-report would therefore be highly desirable (e.g., Charman & Cahill, 2012). Consequently, we examine whether witnesses’ non-verbal behaviors during a lineup procedure—which can only be uncovered by video-recording their identifications—can postdict accuracy. Such non-verbal postdictors are particularly desirable given their lower susceptibility to distortion. Therefore, this study examines whether there are behavioral cues that can differentiate accurate from inaccurate witnesses. 
The second question this study addresses is whether video-recording affects the identification decisions that witnesses make. If video-recording does not affect witnesses’ decisions, this experiment will be a critical supplement to persuasive attempts to encourage police departments to adopt video-recording. However, if video-recording does affect choosing, this would be essential information for psychological researchers to know before continuing to advocate for this recommendation. Why might video-recording affect witness choosing? One possibility is that video-recording makes the potential for contradiction or embarrassment salient. If so, witnesses’ willingness to choose a photo (and potentially be wrong) might diminish, or witnesses may express lower confidence in their identifications. Research showing that witnesses produce lower confidence reports in public (cf. private) provides some support for this possibility (Shaw, Appio, Zerr, & Pontoski, 2007; Shaw, Zerr, & Woythaler, 2001). Alternatively, video-recording might make witnesses more likely to choose a photo because they want to show others that they are a ‘good’ witness. Therefore, as described below, we manipulate whether witnesses are aware of being video-recorded during their lineup procedure, and, among those who are aware, whether they are told that video-recording is standard protocol (thereby minimizing the salience of subsequent evaluation) or whether they are told it will be evaluated by peers (thereby maximizing the salience of potential negative evaluations). Should witness choosing and/or confidence be affected by the explanation for the video-recording, our data will advance our understanding of theoretical models of eyewitness decision-making by, for instance, expanding the constellation of variables known to shift witnesses’ willingness to choose (i.e., their decision criterion, e.g., Dobolyi & Dodson, 2013; Palmer & Brewer, 2012).
registration_responses.q4: We expect inaccurate witnesses to show more non-verbal signs of uncertainty, specifically touching the face while examining the photospread, making noises suggestive of uncertainty (e.g., sighs, groans), re-adjusting the lineup, and displaying facial signs of uncertainty (e.g., grimacing), and non-verbal wavering (e.g., going back and forth between two photos). Given multiple possible hypotheses regarding the effect of videotaping on witness choosing and/or confidence, we treat these questions as exploratory, and thus do not make predictions.

registration_responses.q14: Because we have two main research questions (i.e., whether non-verbal cues postdict witness accuracy, and whether videotaping affects witness choosing/confidence), our required sample size is determined by the analysis that requires more participants. As we explain in more detail below (in the analysis section), testing the effects of videotaping on witness choosing behavior requires an ROC analysis to differentiate between changes in decision criterion and changes in discriminability (e.g., see Wixted & Mickes, 2012); because ROC analyses require particularly large numbers of participants to run, our sample size requirement is based off of this analysis. ROC analyses within eyewitness studies tend to use sample sizes of approximately 220-300 participants per ROC curve (e.g., Gronlund et al., 2012; Mickes, Flowe, & Wixted, 2012). Because we will construct 3 such curves (one for each video condition), we will therefore collect a total of 900 participants (300/condition).

attributes.title: Deployment-related outcomes: A systematic review and meta-analysis of individual and job-level predictors
attributes.description: Operational deployment reflects a significant period in military service. Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) among military personnel is an issue that receives a large amount of attention, particularly in the context of operational deployment in relation to the experience of potentially traumatic events (e.g., Adler et al., 2008). A recent meta-analysis of military personnel investigating PTSD following deployment to the Iraq and Afghanistan conflict identified 49 papers emerging between 1991 and 2012 (Hines, et al., 2014). Yet, there is a dearth of meta-analysis investigating the role the job-related demands and resources play in relation to deployment related-outcomes. Personnel serving in deployment contexts also experience other demands, such as sleep disruption, barriers to fulfilling goals, ethical challenges (Kok, Herrell, Grossman, West, & Wilk, 2016; McCauley, Liebling-Kalifani, & Hughes, 2012). Other job-related demands also play a role in individual vulnerability to PTSD. Personnel serving in deployment contexts also experience such demands as sleep disruption, barriers to fulfilling goals, and ethical challenges (Kok, Herrell, Grossman, West, & Wilk, 2016; McCauley, Liebling-Kalifani, & Hughes, 2012). Other job-related demands also play a role in individual vulnerability to PTSD, as do recent life stressors (Bonanno, Galea, Bucciarelli, & Vlahov, 2007). Thus the backdrop of stressors has implication for the emergence of PTSD. Moreover, deployments may result in a range of other debilitating mental health concerns including: cognitive functioning, anxiety, depression, and burnout (Alder, et al., 2017; Black, et al., 2004; Booth-Kewley, et al., 2012). These may arise as a consequence of other job-related factors that have not yet been the focus of attention in the military context.

q1.value: Deployment-related outcomes: A systematic review and meta-analysis of individual and job-level predictors.

q2.value: Monique Crane, Ben Searle, Daniel Gucciardi, Eyal Karin, Thomas Rigotti, Raffael Kalisch, Roz Connor, Samuel Huf, Gavin Hazel

q3.value: Operational deployment reflects a significant period in military service. Other job-related demands also play a role in individual vulnerability to PTSD. Personnel serving in deployment contexts also experience such demands as sleep disruption, barriers to fulfilling goals, and ethical challenges (Kok, Herrell, Grossman, West, & Wilk, 2016; McCauley, Liebling-Kalifani, & Hughes, 2012).
