q4.value:
We aim to make three distinct contributions to the literature. First, we will gain a deeper and integrated understanding of the job-demands that exist in the military deployment setting that impinge on psychological resilience, cognitive and job-performance. Second, we will establish the relative importance of these job-demands in the predicting decrements in these outcomes. Third, we investigate the job-resources and individual-characteristics that moderate these effects and their role in attenuating the negative effects of job-demands. 

This meta-analysis is intended to provide: (i) a useful qualitative and quantitative synthesis of the available evidence regarding the role of job demands and resources in post-deployment outcomes, (ii) identify gaps in current work that may be areas for future research, and (iii) inform the development of a tool for measuring the critical job demands and resources that are likely to affect at-sea post-deployment outcomes in a Navy population. Therefore, the specific aims of this meta-analysis are to:
1.	Determine the variety of job demands and resources most commonly examined in the context of deployment across and between different services (Army, Navy, Air Force). 
2.	Determine which, of those commonly-identified demands grouped into three broad categories (i.e., physical, cognitive, and emotional), have the largest and most consistent associations with outcomes (i.e., mental ill-health, psychological resilience, cognitive and job performance) and whether these associations differ for the different services.
3.	Identify the job-related resources that moderate the association between job demands and outcomes in three broad categories (i.e., physical, cognitive and emotional). 
4.	Identify the individual-related resources that moderate the association between job demands and outcomes. Individual-resources will be groups into three broad categories: (1) resilient beliefs (e.g., self-efficacy, optimism), (2) coping and emotion regulatory strategies (e.g., support seeking, planning, avoidance) and coping resources (e.g., social support networks). 
5.	Identify how long after deployment it takes for effects on wellbeing (e.g., depression, PTSD, anxiety) to emerge.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Meta-analysis and systematic review

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
To be eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis, studies will need to fulfil the following criteria: (i) involve a military population and (ii) measure outcomes (i.e., internalising symptoms of mental ill-health, psychological resilience, cognitive, or job performance) in relation to deployment, and (iii) measure job-related demands that fall into the categories of physical, cognitive or emotional demands  (including combat exposure/ deployment trauma), or resources in the same three categories, or measure individual-resources that could be conceptualised as either resilient beliefs, coping and emotion regulatory strategies, or coping resources (e.g., social support networks).

We will manually exclude studies when: (i) the samples only include non-military personnel (i.e., military spouses, children of military personnel, unless the military personnel sub-sample can be distinguished), (ii) the study focus excludes deployment or post-deployment periods, (iii) the study is published in a language other than English, (iv) the full-text was unavailable via our university library subscriptions, military contacts/websites, or directly from the corresponding author (i.e., 2 email requests/reminders, separated by 2 weeks); (v) the study contained insufficient data to calculate effect sizes, and such data could not be obtained from the study author (i.e., 2 email requests/reminders, separated by 2 weeks); (vi) the results are published as a conference abstract rather than a full-text (e.g., pre-print) because they are often poorly reported (e.g., Hopewell & Clarke, 2005), (vii) the study focuses on interventions, (viii) the study focuses on organic/physical causes for outcomes (e.g. head injury, exposure to toxin), (ix) the study outcomes focus on externalising disorders (e.g., alcohol or substance use disorders) or suicide-related cognitions and behaviours, and (x) the study is primarily qualitative.

The following intended information sources will be used in order to collect data: 
1.  We will conduct a broad search for primary studies about a particular event (i.e. deployment) in a military population across a range of databases including: Web of Science, Scopus, Embase, Medline, PsychInfo, CINHAL Plus, and Proquest. 
2. We will also conduct a search of the grey literature by placing a request to the five nations (i.e., Australia, Canada, New Zealand, UK, USA) accessed via request to relevant technical panels and contacting prominent researchers in the area. We will also search Defence Government websites for publically available reports.
3. We will also seek unpublished works via research registries and contacting experts in the field. 
4. Backward search: reference lists of eligible studies will be searched manually. 
5. Forward search: articles that have cited eligible studies will be examined manually. 

All materials and literature search results will be stored in Mendeley. This account will be managed by the lead author [MC]. Covidence will be used to import citations from the literature search process, identify duplicates, and screen titles, abstract, and then full texts.

Electronic database searching will be undertaken by MC with the assistance of a librarian. Three reviewers [MC and GH] will execute the initial screening process independently with a 30% overlap in screening material. During this process the title and abstract are first assessed against the eligibility criteria followed by a full-text review. When a decision cannot be made based solely on the title and abstract, the full text will be reviewed. A third member of the research team [DG or TR] will adjudicate any disagreements regarding study eligibility between the two primary assessors. Reasons for study exclusion will be summarised as part of the search and data extraction flow diagram. 

After this initial search process three authors [MC, BS, GH] will then examine these primary studies on the basis of pre-determined criteria and only include studies in the meta-analytic database if they satisfied in inclusion criteria specified previously. Coding will be conducted independently and in duplicate for 30% of the initial papers (Johnson & Hennessy, 2019). Two members of the research team [MC and GH] will extract all data items from primary studies using a pre-determined form or request them from the corresponding author of eligible studies where that information is unavailable in the full text, with up to 2 reminder emails each 7 days apart. A second member of the research team [BS or DG] will assess a random sample of 30% of data extraction forms to check accuracy and consistency.

q13.value:
Time period of the search will be from inception to the date of the electronic search.  Below we provide specific information regarding each dimension of PICO that defines our study sampling frame:
1.	P: Population - Military personnel will be the focus of this meta-analysis. For the purposes of this review, military personnel include all services (i.e., Army, Navy, Air Force). 
2.	I: Intervention/Event – In this particular meta-analysis we will not be examining interventions, but rather exploring a particular event (deployment). In particular, the outcomes will be measured in relation to deployment. 
3.	C: Comparator – For this analysis, we will be comparing a set of distinct job-related resources and demands that will be grouped into three distinct categories: (1) physical, (2) cognitive and (3) emotional. We will also compare three distinct categories of individual resources: (1) resilient beliefs (e.g., self-efficacy, optimism), (2) coping and emotion regulatory strategies (e.g., support seeking, planning, avoidance) and coping resources (e.g., social support networks). We will also compare different services (Army, Navy, Air Force) and sex (male vs female) if sample size permits. Information about these aspects will be extracted from the papers and used in the analysis.
4.	O: Outcome- We will focus on several primary outcomes relating to emotional resilience, cognitive outcomes and job performance. These would have been measured in relation to deployment (i.e. post-deployment or pre-post deployment). Measurements could be self-reports but other possibilities include: clinical interviews (e.g. for emotional resilience); standardised assessments (e.g. for cognitive outcomes such as attention or executive functioning); and via third-party evaluations (e.g. for job performance).

question.value: Not relevant

We will focus on several primary outcomes relating to emotional, cognitive, and job performance resilience in relation to a demanding event: deployment. These outcomes are anticipated to be measured in many ways across the studies, which are listed and defined below: 
1.	Affective symptoms: In order to categorize outcomes in this meta-category, the description of the DSM-5 disorders under depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, trauma and stress-related disorders, and dissociative disorders were used as a reference guide. This meta-category maps several symptoms associated with anger, anxiety, depression, emotional health, frustration, and fear.
2.	Non-clinical stress-related outcomes:  these are non-clinical stress-related outcomes such as stress and burnout. Recent research has confirmed that clinical disorders (e.g. depression) and burnout greatly overlap (Ahola, Hakanen, Perhoniemi, & Mutanen, 2014; Ahola et al., 2005), there are various studies focusing on the burnout construct, and therefore important to consider as a separate outcome relating to emotional resilience. This category includes burnout both as a single score and as emotional exhaustion. Stress defines a neuroendocrine hyper-activation state of response mechanisms to environmental (i.e., physical and/or psychosocial) stimuli (so-called stressors) accompanied by heightened alertness, and affective or neurotic symptoms (Contrada, 2010; Dallman & Hellhammer, 2010). Some of the operationalisations of stress are job tension, job strain, distress, conflict stress, and psychological distress.
3.	Measures of resilience or adjustment: relate to the perception that one is robust or able to quickly adjust to stressors or adversity (Kalisch et al., 2017). While these outcomes are often highly related to both affective symptoms and non-clinical stress-related outcomes, they are often measured as distinct and therefore it is important to consider them as a separate outcome. 
4.	Cognitive outcomes: are measures that relate to cognitive functioning or impairment. Different levels of cognitive impairment can relate to both symptoms of mental ill-health and the job-demand context (e.g., poor sleep). Such impairments may relate to memory, attention, executive functioning, cognitive failures, cognitive fatigue, semantic memory and fluency etc. Cognitive outcomes of interest will not be limited a-priori, rather we intend to identify a wide range of cognitive outcomes that have been explored in relation to the post-deployment context. 
5.	Job performance: overall job performance consists of both task performance and organisational citizenship behaviours (OCBs). Task performance involves behaviours that directly affect organizations’ technical cores via technical processes, whereas OCBs are discretionary behaviours that improve the organizational, psychological, and/or social environments in which organizations’ technical cores function (Motowidlo & Van Scotter, 1994).  Such measures may include self or other ratings of job performance.

We will extract data from eligible studies on:
1.	the nature of the publication (i.e., first author name, year of publication, study location, study duration, study design, type of publication [e.g., peer-reviewed article, dissertation], evidence of pre-registration)
2.	participant characteristics (e.g., service (Army), rank (GE vs officer), size of sample, age-range, language (English), gender (male vs female), country (UK, Australia), occupational context (engineer), average length of service)
3.	the type of outcomes studied (e.g., depression, resilience, executive functioning).
4.	specific job demands measure used, job demands construct measured, and the job demands cluster (physical, cognitive, emotional).
5.	specific job resources measure used, job resources construct measured, and the job resources cluster (physical, cognitive, emotional).
6.	specific individual-resources measure used, individual-resources construct measured, and the individual-resources cluster (resilient beliefs, coping and emotion regulatory strategies, coping resources).
7.	deployment characteristics: length, location, mission status (international policing, counter piracy, illegal fishing, supporting domestic boarder protection, peace keeping, international exercises, conflict, diplomacy, humanitarian, disaster relief, aide the community). 
8.	study design (cross-sectional, cohort, longitudinal, diary studies (e.g., experiential studies)).
9.	timing of post-deployment measurements (days/months post-deployment).
10.	specific outcome measured, measured used and method of data collection.
11.	method of data collection (Q=questionnaire, I=interview, C=cognitive assessment tasks).
12.	means, measures of dispersion, and correlations between study variables where available 
13.	reliability estimates of moderator and outcome variables.
14.	the source of the ratings of moderator and outcome variables (e.g., self-report, informant-report, objective data).
15.	the statistical technique employed for the primary analysis of deployment effects.


All statistical analyses will performed using version 16 of the STATA programme. We are interested in the heterogeneity in effect sizes (Quintana et al., 2015) to determine whether studies are comparable. These differences can relate to study design, outcome measures, populations and whether these aspects are comparable. We expect sufficient methodological heterogeneity to warrant the synthesis of pooled standardised mean differences using a random effects meta-analysis model. The resulting pooled effect size represents an estimate of the mean of the distribution of true effects. 

Given that we are interested in the relationships between deployment job demands and the moderating role of job and individual-resources we will use the Fisher Z with 95% CI for cross-sectional studies that only observe correlations. Studies that are exploring mean-differences will be analysed with Hedge’s g (Lakens, 2013), as a separate subset. Studies that investigate prevalence of a disorder as a categorical variable will be analysed using odds-ratio. Issues of heterogeneity will be addressed by exploring whether sub-groups within the studies (e.g. service) account for variability across studies. 

Publication bias will be assessed using Egger’s test (Egger et al., 1997) and funnel plots, where asymmetry is interpreted as evidence of publication bias (Lau et al., 2006). 

Heterogeneity between studies will be evaluated using the χ2 test and I2 statistic. For the χ2 test, p-values lower than .05 indicate heterogeneity. The related I2 statistic is a percentage that represents the proportion of observed variation that can be attributed to the actual difference between studies. I2 thresholds have been proposed (Higgins et al., 2003), whereby higher I2 values indicating greater variability among studies than would be expected by chance alone (range: 0–100%). The I2 statistic is not biased by the number of studies in the sample. Statistical heterogeneity will be assessed using I2 (proportion of total variance in effect estimates that is due to heterogeneity rather than sampling error; 0%-40% = might not be important; 30%-60% = may represent moderate heterogeneity; 50%-90% = may represent substantial heterogeneity; and 75%-100% = considerable heterogeneity; Higgins et al., 2003).  Potential sources of heterogeneity will also be investigated through a sensitivity analysis, which estimated the distinct effect size by aspects such as service (e.g., Army, Navy, Air force), sex, methodology (e.g., cross-sectional vs longitudinal). Moreover, we will explore the differing relationship between particular clusters of demands and resources on the specific outcomes.

registration_responses.q1: Deployment-related outcomes: A systematic review and meta-analysis of individual and job-level predictors.
registration_responses.q2: Monique Crane, Ben Searle, Daniel Gucciardi, Eyal Karin, Thomas Rigotti, Raffael Kalisch, Roz Connor, Samuel Huf, Gavin Hazel
registration_responses.q3: Operational deployment reflects a significant period in military service. Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) among military personnel is an issue that receives a large amount of attention, particularly in the context of operational deployment in relation to the experience of potentially traumatic events (e.g., Adler et al., 2008). A recent meta-analysis of military personnel investigating PTSD following deployment to the Iraq and Afghanistan conflict identified 49 papers emerging between 1991 and 2012 (Hines, et al., 2014). Yet, there is a dearth of meta-analysis investigating the role the job-related demands and resources play in relation to deployment related-outcomes. Personnel serving in deployment contexts also experience other demands, such as sleep disruption, barriers to fulfilling goals, ethical challenges (Kok, Herrell, Grossman, West, & Wilk, 2016; McCauley, Liebling-Kalifani, & Hughes, 2012). Other job-related demands also play a role in individual vulnerability to PTSD. Personnel serving in deployment contexts also experience such demands as sleep disruption, barriers to fulfilling goals, and ethical challenges (Kok, Herrell, Grossman, West, & Wilk, 2016; McCauley, Liebling-Kalifani, & Hughes, 2012). Other job-related demands also play a role in individual vulnerability to PTSD, as do recent life stressors (Bonanno, Galea, Bucciarelli, & Vlahov, 2007). Thus the backdrop of stressors has implication for the emergence of PTSD. Moreover, deployments may result in a range of other debilitating mental health concerns including: cognitive functioning, anxiety, depression, and burnout (Alder, et al., 2017; Black, et al., 2004; Booth-Kewley, et al., 2012). These may arise as a consequence of other job-related factors that have not yet been the focus of attention in the military context.
registration_responses.q4:
We aim to make three distinct contributions to the literature. First, we will gain a deeper and integrated understanding of the job-demands that exist in the military deployment setting that impinge on psychological resilience, cognitive and job-performance. Second, we will establish the relative importance of these job-demands in the predicting decrements in these outcomes. Third, we investigate the job-resources and individual-characteristics that moderate these effects and their role in attenuating the negative effects of job-demands. 

This meta-analysis is intended to provide: (i) a useful qualitative and quantitative synthesis of the available evidence regarding the role of job demands and resources in post-deployment outcomes, (ii) identify gaps in current work that may be areas for future research, and (iii) inform the development of a tool for measuring the critical job demands and resources that are likely to affect at-sea post-deployment outcomes in a Navy population. Therefore, the specific aims of this meta-analysis are to:
1.	Determine the variety of job demands and resources most commonly examined in the context of deployment across and between different services (Army, Navy, Air Force). 
2.	Determine which, of those commonly-identified demands grouped into three broad categories (i.e., physical, cognitive, and emotional), have the largest and most consistent associations with outcomes (i.e., mental ill-health, psychological resilience, cognitive and job performance) and whether these associations differ for the different services.
3.	Identify the job-related resources that moderate the association between job demands and outcomes in three broad categories (i.e., physical, cognitive and emotional). 
4.	Identify the individual-related resources that moderate the association between job demands and outcomes. Individual-resources will be groups into three broad categories: (1) resilient beliefs (e.g., self-efficacy, optimism), (2) coping and emotion regulatory strategies (e.g., support seeking, planning, avoidance) and coping resources (e.g., social support networks). 
5.	Identify how long after deployment it takes for effects on wellbeing (e.g., depression, PTSD, anxiety) to emerge.
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13:
Time period of the search will be from inception to the date of the electronic search.  Below we provide specific information regarding each dimension of PICO that defines our study sampling frame:
1.	P: Population - Military personnel will be the focus of this meta-analysis. For the purposes of this review, military personnel include all services (i.e., Army, Navy, Air Force). 
2.	I: Intervention/Event – In this particular meta-analysis we will not be examining interventions, but rather exploring a particular event (deployment). In particular, the outcomes will be measured in relation to deployment. 
3.	C: Comparator – For this analysis, we will be comparing a set of distinct job-related resources and demands that will be grouped into three distinct categories: (1) physical, (2) cognitive and (3) emotional. We will also compare three distinct categories of individual resources: (1) resilient beliefs (e.g., self-efficacy, optimism), (2) coping and emotion regulatory strategies (e.g., support seeking, planning, avoidance) and coping resources (e.g., social support networks). We will also compare different services (Army, Navy, Air Force) and sex (male vs female) if sample size permits. Information about these aspects will be extracted from the papers and used in the analysis.
4.	O: Outcome- We will focus on several primary outcomes relating to emotional resilience, cognitive outcomes and job performance. These would have been measured in relation to deployment (i.e. post-deployment or pre-post deployment). Measurements could be self-reports but other possibilities include: clinical interviews (e.g. for emotional resilience); standardised assessments (e.g. for cognitive outcomes such as attention or executive functioning); and via third-party evaluations (e.g. for job performance).
registration_responses.q8.question: Meta-analysis and systematic review
registration_responses.q12.question:
To be eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis, studies will need to fulfil the following criteria: (i) involve a military population and (ii) measure outcomes (i.e., internalising symptoms of mental ill-health, psychological resilience, cognitive, or job performance) in relation to deployment, and (iii) measure job-related demands that fall into the categories of physical, cognitive or emotional demands  (including combat exposure/ deployment trauma), or resources in the same three categories, or measure individual-resources that could be conceptualised as either resilient beliefs, coping and emotion regulatory strategies, or coping resources (e.g., social support networks).

We will manually exclude studies when: (i) the samples only include non-military personnel (i.e., military spouses, children of military personnel, unless the military personnel sub-sample can be distinguished), (ii) the study focus excludes deployment or post-deployment periods, (iii) the study is published in a language other than English, (iv) the full-text was unavailable via our university library subscriptions, military contacts/websites, or directly from the corresponding author (i.e., 2 email requests/reminders, separated by 2 weeks); (v) the study contained insufficient data to calculate effect sizes, and such data could not be obtained from the study author (i.e., 2 email requests/reminders, separated by 2 weeks); (vi) the results are published as a conference abstract rather than a full-text (e.g., pre-print) because they are often poorly reported (e.g., Hopewell & Clarke, 2005), (vii) the study focuses on interventions, (viii) the study focuses on organic/physical causes for outcomes (e.g. head injury, exposure to toxin), (ix) the study outcomes focus on externalising disorders (e.g., alcohol or substance use disorders) or suicide-related cognitions and behaviours, and (x) the study is primarily qualitative.

The following intended information sources will be used in order to collect data: 
1.  We will conduct a broad search for primary studies about a particular event (i.e. deployment) in a military population across a range of databases including: Web of Science, Scopus, Embase, Medline, PsychInfo, CINHAL Plus, and Proquest. 
2. We will also conduct a search of the grey literature by placing a request to the five nations (i.e., Australia, Canada, New Zealand, UK, USA) accessed via request to relevant technical panels and contacting prominent researchers in the area. We will also search Defence Government websites for publically available reports.
3. We will also seek unpublished works via research registries and contacting experts in the field. 
4. Backward search: reference lists of eligible studies will be searched manually. 
5. Forward search: articles that have cited eligible studies will be examined manually. 

All materials and literature search results will be stored in Mendeley. This account will be managed by the lead author [MC]. Covidence will be used to import citations from the literature search process, identify duplicates, and screen titles, abstract, and then full texts.

Electronic database searching will be undertaken by MC with the assistance of a librarian. Three reviewers [MC and GH] will execute the initial screening process independently with a 30% overlap in screening material. During this process the title and abstract are first assessed against the eligibility criteria followed by a full-text review. When a decision cannot be made based solely on the title and abstract, the full text will be reviewed. A third member of the research team [DG or TR] will adjudicate any disagreements regarding study eligibility between the two primary assessors. Reasons for study exclusion will be summarised as part of the search and data extraction flow diagram. 

After this initial search process three authors [MC, BS, GH] will then examine these primary studies on the basis of pre-determined criteria and only include studies in the meta-analytic database if they satisfied in inclusion criteria specified previously. Coding will be conducted independently and in duplicate for 30% of the initial papers (Johnson & Hennessy, 2019). Two members of the research team [MC and GH] will extract all data items from primary studies using a pre-determined form or request them from the corresponding author of eligible studies where that information is unavailable in the full text, with up to 2 reminder emails each 7 days apart. A second member of the research team [BS or DG] will assess a random sample of 30% of data extraction forms to check accuracy and consistency.
registration_responses.q16.question: Not relevant
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will focus on several primary outcomes relating to emotional, cognitive, and job performance resilience in relation to a demanding event: deployment. These outcomes are anticipated to be measured in many ways across the studies, which are listed and defined below: 
1.	Affective symptoms: In order to categorize outcomes in this meta-category, the description of the DSM-5 disorders under depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, trauma and stress-related disorders, and dissociative disorders were used as a reference guide. This meta-category maps several symptoms associated with anger, anxiety, depression, emotional health, frustration, and fear.
2.	Non-clinical stress-related outcomes:  these are non-clinical stress-related outcomes such as stress and burnout. Recent research has confirmed that clinical disorders (e.g. depression) and burnout greatly overlap (Ahola, Hakanen, Perhoniemi, & Mutanen, 2014; Ahola et al., 2005), there are various studies focusing on the burnout construct, and therefore important to consider as a separate outcome relating to emotional resilience. This category includes burnout both as a single score and as emotional exhaustion. Stress defines a neuroendocrine hyper-activation state of response mechanisms to environmental (i.e., physical and/or psychosocial) stimuli (so-called stressors) accompanied by heightened alertness, and affective or neurotic symptoms (Contrada, 2010; Dallman & Hellhammer, 2010). Some of the operationalisations of stress are job tension, job strain, distress, conflict stress, and psychological distress.
3.	Measures of resilience or adjustment: relate to the perception that one is robust or able to quickly adjust to stressors or adversity (Kalisch et al., 2017). While these outcomes are often highly related to both affective symptoms and non-clinical stress-related outcomes, they are often measured as distinct and therefore it is important to consider them as a separate outcome. 
4.	Cognitive outcomes: are measures that relate to cognitive functioning or impairment. Different levels of cognitive impairment can relate to both symptoms of mental ill-health and the job-demand context (e.g., poor sleep). Such impairments may relate to memory, attention, executive functioning, cognitive failures, cognitive fatigue, semantic memory and fluency etc. Cognitive outcomes of interest will not be limited a-priori, rather we intend to identify a wide range of cognitive outcomes that have been explored in relation to the post-deployment context. 
5.	Job performance: overall job performance consists of both task performance and organisational citizenship behaviours (OCBs). Task performance involves behaviours that directly affect organizations’ technical cores via technical processes, whereas OCBs are discretionary behaviours that improve the organizational, psychological, and/or social environments in which organizations’ technical cores function (Motowidlo & Van Scotter, 1994).  Such measures may include self or other ratings of job performance.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will extract data from eligible studies on:
1.	the nature of the publication (i.e., first author name, year of publication, study location, study duration, study design, type of publication [e.g., peer-reviewed article, dissertation], evidence of pre-registration)
2.	participant characteristics (e.g., service (Army), rank (GE vs officer), size of sample, age-range, language (English), gender (male vs female), country (UK, Australia), occupational context (engineer), average length of service)
3.	the type of outcomes studied (e.g., depression, resilience, executive functioning).
4.	specific job demands measure used, job demands construct measured, and the job demands cluster (physical, cognitive, emotional).
5.	specific job resources measure used, job resources construct measured, and the job resources cluster (physical, cognitive, emotional).
6.	specific individual-resources measure used, individual-resources construct measured, and the individual-resources cluster (resilient beliefs, coping and emotion regulatory strategies, coping resources).
7.	deployment characteristics: length, location, mission status (international policing, counter piracy, illegal fishing, supporting domestic boarder protection, peace keeping, international exercises, conflict, diplomacy, humanitarian, disaster relief, aide the community). 
8.	study design (cross-sectional, cohort, longitudinal, diary studies (e.g., experiential studies)).
9.	timing of post-deployment measurements (days/months post-deployment).
10.	specific outcome measured, measured used and method of data collection.
11.	method of data collection (Q=questionnaire, I=interview, C=cognitive assessment tasks).
12.	means, measures of dispersion, and correlations between study variables where available 
13.	reliability estimates of moderator and outcome variables.
14.	the source of the ratings of moderator and outcome variables (e.g., self-report, informant-report, objective data).
15.	the statistical technique employed for the primary analysis of deployment effects.


All statistical analyses will performed using version 16 of the STATA programme. We are interested in the heterogeneity in effect sizes (Quintana et al., 2015) to determine whether studies are comparable. These differences can relate to study design, outcome measures, populations and whether these aspects are comparable. We expect sufficient methodological heterogeneity to warrant the synthesis of pooled standardised mean differences using a random effects meta-analysis model. The resulting pooled effect size represents an estimate of the mean of the distribution of true effects. 

Given that we are interested in the relationships between deployment job demands and the moderating role of job and individual-resources we will use the Fisher Z with 95% CI for cross-sectional studies that only observe correlations. Studies that are exploring mean-differences will be analysed with Hedge’s g (Lakens, 2013), as a separate subset. Studies that investigate prevalence of a disorder as a categorical variable will be analysed using odds-ratio. Issues of heterogeneity will be addressed by exploring whether sub-groups within the studies (e.g. service) account for variability across studies. 

Publication bias will be assessed using Egger’s test (Egger et al., 1997) and funnel plots, where asymmetry is interpreted as evidence of publication bias (Lau et al., 2006). 

Heterogeneity between studies will be evaluated using the χ2 test and I2 statistic. For the χ2 test, p-values lower than .05 indicate heterogeneity. The related I2 statistic is a percentage that represents the proportion of observed variation that can be attributed to the actual difference between studies. I2 thresholds have been proposed (Higgins et al., 2003), whereby higher I2 values indicating greater variability among studies than would be expected by chance alone (range: 0–100%). The I2 statistic is not biased by the number of studies in the sample. Statistical heterogeneity will be assessed using I2 (proportion of total variance in effect estimates that is due to heterogeneity rather than sampling error; 0%-40% = might not be important; 30%-60% = may represent moderate heterogeneity; 50%-90% = may represent substantial heterogeneity; and 75%-100% = considerable heterogeneity; Higgins et al., 2003).  Potential sources of heterogeneity will also be investigated through a sensitivity analysis, which estimated the distinct effect size by aspects such as service (e.g., Army, Navy, Air force), sex, methodology (e.g., cross-sectional vs longitudinal). Moreover, we will explore the differing relationship between particular clusters of demands and resources on the specific outcomes.

q3.value: Despite the abundance of literature in trade preference scholarship, we know little about news media's coverage of trade policy and its effects on people's trade preferences. This study explores how news stories about U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods impact people's opinions about tariff policies, China, and the economy.

q4.value:
H1a: Because news media shape people’s opinions on foreign policy, people who read pro-tariff news stories are more likely to support tariffs than people who read anti-tariff news stories.
H1b: Because news media shape people’s opinions on other countries, people who read pro-tariff news stories will have a lower opinion of China than people who read anti-tariff news stories.
H1c: Because news media shape people’s confidence in one’s local economy, people who read pro-tariff news stories will have lower confidence in the U.S. economy than people who read anti-tariff news stories.

H2a: Because news media framing can make issue position more salient, people who read pro-tariff news stories with war metaphors are more likely to support tariffs than people who read pro-tariff news stories without no war metaphors.
H2b: Because news media framing can make opinions about states more salient, people who read pro-tariff news stories with war metaphors will have a lower opinion of China than people who read pro-tariff news stories without no war metaphors.

H3: Because people match style when communicating linguistically, people who read articles with war metaphors will be primed to use more aggressive language to explain their position.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a 2x2 between-subject design with two factors. The first factor is sentiment towards U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods, which has two levels (pro-tariff and anti-tariff). The second factor is the use of war metaphors, which has two levels (the presence of war metaphors, no war metaphors). In addition to these four conditions, there will be a control group that reads an article that does not have to do with tariffs, trade, foreign policy or economics.

question.value: Data are being/will be collected using a survey experiment that is designed and hosted on Qualtrics. Human subjects are recruited using the survey sampling firm Lucid; these participants will be paid through the sampling firm. Participants must be at least 18 years old and a member of the Lucid survey pool. Data collection will last one week (2/20/2020 to 2/26/2020).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 600 participants.

q14.value: The goal of this sample size is to have at least 100 participants per condition.

q15.value: We do not anticipate terminating our data collection before the sample size is reached, as we are using a survey sampling firm.

question.value:
We manipulated the news stimuli that will be seen by the participants. There are five levels of this categorical variable (based on the two factors and control):
1) A pro-tariff article with war metaphors.
2) A pro-tariff article without war metaphors.
3) An anti-tariff article with war metaphors.
4) An anti-tariff article without war metaphors.
5) A control article that does not discuss tariffs, trade, economic or foreign policy.

Participants will be asked a battery of questions after reading the stimuli. This includes:
1) Opinions about current U.S.-China tariffs (2-items: support, do not support)
2) Opinions about China (as a partner: 4-pt scale; in general: 100-pt thermometer)
3) Opinions about the economy (6-pt scale)
4) Opinions about how politicians handle the economy (6 pt-scale)

In addition to this, participants will answer open-ended surveys. We plan on constructing text-based variables using natural language processing. The following three variables will be extacted: positive and negative sentiment about the economy, positive and negative sentiment about China, and the use of aggressive language.

I will use a 2x2 one way ANOVA to test the hypothesis. To confirm the results of this analysis, I will also perform three multiple regression with controls. The first regression is a logit regression, with the DV being support for tariffs. The second regression's DV will be opinions about China. The third regression's DV will be opinions about the economy. The fourth regression's DV will be opinions about politicians. IV's for all regressions will include the two factors (pro/anti-tariff attitudes and use of war metaphors). I will also include the following controls: (1) party affiliation, (2) economic attitudes, (3) economic knowledge, (4) age, (5) race, and (6) income.

q20.value: For the regression, all categorical variables (i.e., the factors) will be recoded as dummy variables. Likert scale questions (e.g., opinion about the economy) will be treated as continuous variables. Depending on the model, the independent variables of the regression may be standardized.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < 0.05 criteria for determining whether the ANOVA or regressions have statistically significant results.

q22.value: Outliers will be included in the analysis. In order for a participant to be included, they must have completed the whole survey.

q23.value: Participants must have completed the survey to be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We collect but do not hypothesize on, information about consumption, political interest, political knowledge, and self-efficacy. These may be included in our analysis as controls.

question10b.value:
MATERIALS/STIMULI

The stimuli will consist of two novel categories of cartoon monsters called “Mizulees” and “Nedrils”. The stimuli vary along four binary feature dimensions: type of horns, type of arms, type of marks, and type of eyes. The category structure consists of (a) one diagnostic feature that separates the two categories (the horns); (b) one feature equally distributed across both categories (the eyes); and (c) two features assigned into a pair of correlated features and equally distributed across both categories (the arms and the marks). Correlated feature pairs are feature dimensions that always occur together, regardless of category membership. All possible feature combinations were made, generating a total of 8 unique monsters per category. For the feature inference test, various images (i.e. a cloud, brick wall, tree, etc.) were used to hide the monsters so that only one feature was shown.

PROCEDURE:

Participants will be seated with the experimenter while doing the experiment. Instructions will be read out to all participants. 

The trial orders will be randomized for each participant to avoid any order effects. 

For the first task participants will see a monster appear in the middle of the screen and will have to categorize the monster based on if the participant thinks the monster is a “Mizulee” or a “Nedril”. Participants make responses by pressing either the left or right arrow key corresponding to the monster category. This task will contain 32 trials where after making a response, the participant will be told whether they were correct or incorrect. Each monster will appear on the screen for 30 seconds and at this time, the participants have to make their response. The monster will remain on the screen for an additional 1 second so that the participants have a chance to look over the features. 

The second task will be feature inference and consist of 14 two alternative forced-choice trials. The monster will appear on the screen for 30 seconds and will be covered by an object (i.e. a cloud, brick wall, etc.) Only one feature of the monster will be visible to the participant. Two choices of the matching feature will be displayed on the bottom of the screen and participants must choose which feature they think corresponds to the feature seen on the monster. This judgement will be based on what the participant learned about the monster categories in the learning phase. There is a total of 4 correlations trials with correct answers, and 10 control trials with no right or wrong answer. This was done to alleviate any carry-over effects from the previous trial, as well as, allow for more trials in this phase.

The study will end with a thank you slide, and participants will be given credit for participation.

question4b.value: The participants must be between the ages of 4- to 9-years old. They must have normal or corrected vision. They must also not be diagnosed with an attention disorder.

question1a.value:
1. We predict that there is a trade-off when children learn categories:
A) Children who struggle to learn unidimensional category rules during learning will show a greater knowledge of feature correlations.

question2a.value: N/A since this is a correlational design

question3a.value: There will be no variable check in this experiment because there is no manipulation.

question5a.value:
Selective attention allows us to focus on features that are predictive of category membership and ignore "irrelevant " stimuli. However, this serves as a caveat when category members have common features independent of category membership. These features would be considered irrelevant because they hold no information about what category a member belongs to. There is a debate as to whether or not children are able to selectively attend, and if they are unable, do they pick up on the extraneous features because of their divided attention (Deng & Sloutsky, 2015; Rabi, Miles & Minda, 2015)

Deng and Sloutsky (2015) claimed that children pay attention to extraneous features and learn category rules. In their study, they found that children relied more on probabilistic features regardless of the condition. On the other hand, Rabi and Minda (2014) suggest that children are not holistic learners and can selectively attend. Perhaps, there is too much information to learn with extraneous features that selectively attending is an easier learning strategy. 

Children are presumed to perform better in tasks that involve picking up on correlated features because children struggle to selectively attend. For instance, Kemler (1984) was able to demonstrate how using fictitious categories allowed children to learn family resemblance-structured categories more efficiently than categories that had a single defining feature. The children in the Kemler study were unable to extract information about the single defining feature categories due to their lack of selective attention. However, they were able to learn the family resemblance categories due to their ability to retain information about the non-deterministic features.

question6a.value:
Since there is a debate in the literature on how children learn categories, there are competing theories that lead to two different outcomes. 

If children are unable to selectively attend but learn the feature correlations, this would support the theory that children are holistic learners. However, if children are unable to learn the category and unable to pick up on the common correlated extraneous features, then children are not holistic learners.

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
MATERIALS/STIMULI

The stimuli will consist of two novel categories of cartoon monsters called “Mizulees” and “Nedrils”. The stimuli vary along four binary feature dimensions: type of horns, type of arms, type of marks, and type of eyes. The category structure consists of (a) one diagnostic feature that separates the two categories (the horns); (b) one feature equally distributed across both categories (the eyes); and (c) two features assigned into a pair of correlated features and equally distributed across both categories (the arms and the marks). Correlated feature pairs are feature dimensions that always occur together, regardless of category membership. All possible feature combinations were made, generating a total of 8 unique monsters per category. For the feature inference test, various images (i.e. a cloud, brick wall, tree, etc.) were used to hide the monsters so that only one feature was shown.

PROCEDURE:

Participants will be seated with the experimenter while doing the experiment. Instructions will be read out to all participants. 

The trial orders will be randomized for each participant to avoid any order effects. 

For the first task participants will see a monster appear in the middle of the screen and will have to categorize the monster based on if the participant thinks the monster is a “Mizulee” or a “Nedril”. Participants make responses by pressing either the left or right arrow key corresponding to the monster category. This task will contain 32 trials where after making a response, the participant will be told whether they were correct or incorrect. Each monster will appear on the screen for 30 seconds and at this time, the participants have to make their response. The monster will remain on the screen for an additional 1 second so that the participants have a chance to look over the features. 

The second task will be feature inference and consist of 14 two alternative forced-choice trials. The monster will appear on the screen for 30 seconds and will be covered by an object (i.e. a cloud, brick wall, etc.) Only one feature of the monster will be visible to the participant. Two choices of the matching feature will be displayed on the bottom of the screen and participants must choose which feature they think corresponds to the feature seen on the monster. This judgement will be based on what the participant learned about the monster categories in the learning phase. There is a total of 4 correlations trials with correct answers, and 10 control trials with no right or wrong answer. This was done to alleviate any carry-over effects from the previous trial, as well as, allow for more trials in this phase.

The study will end with a thank you slide, and participants will be given credit for participation.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
1. Category learning performance: will be calculated by the mean correct and incorrect trials in the category learning task. In the dataset, the participant's mean correctness score on category learning will be reported. 

2. Feature Inference performance: will be calculated by the mean number of correct and incorrect trials in the feature inference task.

To determine if performance on the category learning test affects sensitivity to feature correlations we will run a Pearson correlation. (i.e. if learning the category affects learning the feature correlations)

1. Category Learning Performance - DV
2. Feature Inference Performance - DV
3. Participant age - covariate

Participant age may affect the memory load or capacity to hold any amount of information. Ex. older children may be able to store more info than younger children (somewhat can be attributed to working memory).

Based on an effect size determined from previous literature (r = 0.49) in this area, the software G*Power was used to calculate the sample size. The power was set to 0.8 and the alpha was set to .05. This is for a two-tailed test.
We will stop once the planned sample size is achieved.
